title: @Riot, The Lore Retcon Is Painful, And It's Taking Too Long, Finish it Already!
body:
Have you ever heard the phrase regarding the ripping off of a bandaid?

It should be done quickly and completely in one quick shot.

The lore retcon, assuming it needed to happen in the first place, should have been done the same way.

It's been almost a year, and many champion's lore still exist in a pre-retconned world. Jax for example.

@Riot I enjoy and love your game, but your managers must have some serious issues setting deadlines for lore or something because they don't seem to be doing their job. 

We've seen RIot develop lore at a much faster rate than it has in the past year, and while we've had the odd really cool event (Bilgewater) it hasn't seemed like we've gotten any consistent lore releases happening like we used too.

Lore releases happen at a snails pace these days, and never actually seem to have any global significance to Runeterra.

Heck Riot, you guys haven't even finished the retcon, which I would think would have been your number 1 priority for the last year!

What's taking so long Riot?!

replies.body:
Speaking as a writer... doing this stuff well takes *time.*

Quite a bit of it, actually. It's also not something that you can just "throw more people at" in order to make it go faster, because everybody needs to be... aheh... on the same page. The more people you have writing on a group project, the less each person adds due to the increased communication overhead between writers.

I'd rather have a well-designed, cohesive world than a bunch of one-off tales that don't seem to relate to each other in any meaningful way. Plotting something like that out takes a lot of work and a lot of time, especially if it's done right.

But then we have another problem. Narrative retconed the old lore while KNOWING that they are not capable of replacing it soon. Any good writter or anything that is concerned with it plans ahead, even if its not accurate he still plans.

Narrative retconed the old lore but had no plans how to replace it, no ground to stand on.

While a cohesive world is hard to achieve, it isnt THAT hard. If you know the direction your world will take and you already have your world base, then its quite easy.


Andd right now i have a bad opinion on narrative, because there is either 2 possibilities here.

1. They are incompetent and dont know the basics of writing or planing that every begginer knows.

2. They arent doing anything on purpose and just get paid while doing minimal job.


I may be wrong, but for me it looks like this, and i dont know which one of these possibilities is worse.

Mmm, that's fair. I've got about 170k words of fanfic published and I'm about a third of the way done with a fantasy novel. I also run a tabletop gaming session (Shadowrun campaign, about 3 years long now), but that doesn't really involve that much writing. Planning, yes, writing, no. I've done one short collaborative writing project (a short story chronicling a particularly memorable tabletop campaign, maybe twenty thousand words?)

The communication overhead isn't (just) my personal experience, since I've only done the one collaborative writing project. It's also from Ghostcrawler back when he worked on WoW and talked about the difficulties with coordinating quest and world design. I can probably go dig up the quote if you really want, but it's ancient (~5 years now, I think).
